ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This was basically just a way to checkin if I needed it for my thesis.

See my intellectual journal entry for this fall! Getting to spend so much time on an intellectual project has been by turns frustrating, thrilling, and deeply satisfying. Thinking forward, I am both anxious and excited to continue doing different types of research and reading, and to ultimately tie everything together.

My senior thesis idea required me to do a good bit of archival research for the first time in my Yale education---as a HUMS major you have a lot of flexibility over your courses and mine have largely focused on close-reading. The process of having to discover and manage a large amount of primary materials is really something that I think every humanist should have the experience of doing, even if you (like me) do not elect the history major.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: accountability

Weaknesses: takes a lot of self-advocacy, no formal structure, little overhead guidance, a lot of assumption that students know what they are doing

I think that a bit more structure could be nice. Perhaps weekly check-ins are too much to ask, but earlier this semester, I felt adrift and worried about my project. I'm in a much better spot (both practically and affectively) now, but I think that more consultation would have made the process smoother. Other than that, both Professor Grimstad and my advisor have been very encouraging and helpful.

The HUMS senior thesis gives you maximal flexibility in terms of the kind of project you want to execute. Professor Grimstad is also flexible and judicious DUS who will work with you if you have any problems.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would strongly recommend the two-semester senior essay, which will force you to execute a much larger project than you otherwise would be able to get in a single yale course. The one-semester essay is more similar to a long term paper for a junior seminar.
